headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the American Tower's Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Leah Stearns, Se
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the American Tower's Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Leah Stearns, Senior Vice President, Treasurer and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning to discuss our second quarter earning. Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows. First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial resul
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning to discuss our second quarter earning. 
Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows. First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial results. Next, Tom Bartlett, our Executive Vice President and CFO, will provide a more detailed review of our financial and operational performance for the second quarter 2016 as well as our full year outlook for the full year of 2016. And finally, Jim Taiclet, our Chairman, President and CEO, will provide a brief update on our international business and strategy. After these comments, we'll open up the call for your questions. 
Before I begin, I would like to remind you that this call will contain forward-looking statements that involve a number of risks and uncertainties. Examples of these statements include those regarding our expectations for future growth, including our 2016 outlook, foreign currency exchange rates and future operating performance; technology and industry trends; and any other statements regarding matters that are not historical facts. 
You should be aware that certain factors may affect us in the future and could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in these forward-looking statements. Such factors include the risk factories set forth in this morning's press release; those set forth in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015; and in other filings we make with the SEC. We urge you to consider these factors and remind you that we undertake no obligation to update the information contained in this call to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. 
In addition to this morning's press release, we have posted a presentation which we will a reference throughout our prepared remarks, under the Investor Relations step on our website. I'd like to note that we have updated the name of our run rate revenue metric to tenant billing. As we highlighted for you last quarter when we introduced this metric, it reflects the current tenant billings, which are generated by our global portfolio of communications real estate. In addition, in response to recently issued disclosure guidance by the SEC, after today, we will no longer reference our core growth metrics. 
So with that, please turn to Slide 4 of the presentation, which highlights our financial results. During the quarter, property revenue grew approximately 24% to nearly $1.43 billion. Total revenues grew approximately 23% to over $1.44 billion, and net income attributable to American Tower Corporation common stockholders increased by over 24% to $161 million or $0.37 per diluted common share. Our effective tax rate during the quarter was over 18% and included an income tax reserve related to our Viom transaction. For the year, we now expect our effective tax rate will be in the low double digit. Adjusted EBITDA during the quarter grew 14% to approximately $869 million, and consolidated adjusted funds from operations increased by over 10% to approximately $592 million or $1.38 per diluted share. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. As can see from the results we released this morning, we had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and good margin performance across our global asset base. We also declared a common stock div
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. As can see from the results we released this morning, we had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and good margin performance across our global asset base. We also declared a common stock dividend of $0.53 a share, which was up over 20% from the prior year period. And given the close of our Viom transaction in late April, our teams in India are now working hard to seamlessly integrate the more than 42,000 towers we added to our portfolio with that acquisition. 
If you please turn to Slide 6, let's take it a lower-quality quarterly results. You can see that we generated stronger performance with total reported property revenue growth of about 24%. This included total tenant billings growth of over 23%, of which about 8% was organic, driven by consistent demand levels throughout our global footprint. Our total property revenue growth this quarter included a negative 60 basis point impact from a $7 million revenue reserve related to our receivables associated with a tenant in Brazil, which were outstanding at the time of their judicial reorganization filing. Based on our prior experiences with carrier bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings, we expect to pursue the full amount owed to us. Additionally, I would note that this tenant has resumed payments to us for amounts of subsequent to their judicial reorganization filing date. 
Our U.S. property segment generated total reported revenue growth of about 3%, including a negative 1.4% impact from straight-line revenue account recognition. We did not book any decommissioning revenue this quarter as compared to about $8 million recorded in Q2 of last year and $31 million or so booked in Q1. This negatively impacted our U.S. property revenue growth by an additional 1.1%. 
U.S. organic tenant billings growth for the quarter was 5.6%, which again reflects organic build recurring revenue and was right in line with our expectations. Demand trend in the U.S. remain very steady with carriers actively spending to augment their 4G networks. Our international markets generated organic tenant billings growth of 13.7% or 800 basis points higher than that of the U.S. Escalators associated with rising local market inflation contributed about 7% to that growth, while organic new business commencements were an even larger component of the growth in about 7.6%. These were partially offset by churn of just over 1%. 
There was broad strength across our international property segments, with all 3 posting double-digit organic tenant billings growth rates, including 12% in Latin America, 20% in EMEA and over 10% in Asia. Our multinational tenant base in these markets continue to make significant investments in their networks as more and more of their customers gain access to advance headsets, handsets of lower per unit cost and begin to use exponentially more data on those handsets. The benefits of the geographic tenant and technological diversification built into our business model continues to be evidenced by the strong growth rates we were generating in our international markets. 
Finally, on a total property basis, the day one revenue associated with the nearly 57,000 sites we have added since the second quarter of last year, including the Viom, Airtel Nigeria and team Brazil portfolios and roughly 3,400 new builds contributed another 15% to our total tenant billings growth in Q2, bringing the total growth to the nearly 23%. Our new build program remains active, and we constructed nearly 400 towers this quarter with an average day 1 NOI yield of over 10%. 
Moving on to Slide 7. The combination of solid revenue growth and tight cost controls led to strong margin performance across our business. Gross margin in the quarter remained strong at over 68% despite a negative impact of over 10% from passthrough and a negative impact of 4.6% due to addition of new sites, which have lowered initial tenancies and margins. This was supported by strong conversion of revenue to gross margin on legacy sites during the quarter, while our reported conversion of revenue to gross margin was around 49% as a result of the previously mentioned negative impacts of pass-through revenue and lower tenancy new sites, which on a combined basis negatively impacted the reported conversion ratio by about 50%. Our ability to convert revenue to gross margin on our pre-existing sites remain strong and in line with historical norms of well over 90%. 
Finally, our adjusted EBITDA margin was about 60% for the quarter, which includes a negative impact from pass-through of about 9%. This also includes about 4.3% of margin dilution associated with new sites brought into the portfolio since the start of the second quarter last year, including Viom. Cash SG&A as a percentage of revenue was about 8.1% in the quarter and is expected to be right around 8% for the full year. Our adjusted EBITDA and consolidated AFFO growth in the quarter was detailed on Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA grew 14% to about $869 million as a result of our top line growth coupled with the diligent operational expense management. Our solid adjusted EBITDA performance drove growth in consolidated AFFO at slightly lower-than-expected capital improvement capital expenditures. This led to growth in consolidated AFFO of over 10% and growth in consolidated AFFO per share of nearly 10%. The global operational efficiency initiatives that we put into place continue to result in strong profitability for the business. 
Moving on to Slide 9. We remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet with financial policies designed to support this objective by managing risk across the capital structure in support of our investment-grade rating. In the second quarter, we pursued several financing initiatives directly supporting these policies. First, we raised $1 billion in 10-year senior unsecured notes at a historically low coupon rates for ATC in 3 3/8%. This opportunistic transaction increased our liquidity and turned out a significant portion of our floating rate debt. Next, we assumed nearly $800 million of rupee-denominated debt in connection with our acquisition of a majority interest in Viom. We immediately commenced a multiyear process to refinance the existing loans locally at more attractive rates than the initial 11% average coupon. They have already decreased the average cost to about 10.3%. These actions highlight our excellent access to diversified funding sources, including the investment-grade volume market as well as an ability to maintain a substantial base of liquidity system to support our solid balance sheet. As a result, at the end of the second quarter, our net leverage ratio was 5.3x net debt to annualized Q2 adjusted EBITDA with liquidity of over $3 billion. We continue to expect to end the year at 5x net debt or below, and longer term, our target leverage range remains between 3 and 5x.
Turning to Slide 10. Given our solid performance in the first half of the year, continued improvements in foreign currency exchange rate forecast and underlying trends that are consistent with our previous assumptions, we are raising our full year guidance for 2016. At the midpoint of our outlook, we're increasing our expectations for property revenue by $10 million or about 0.2%, resulting in projected reported gross of 21% or so. The increase is being driven by $14 million increase in straight-line revenue and $7 million in favorability in organic tenant billing revenue across our property segment. This favorability is being partially offset by about $7 million from the reserve book this quarter in Brazil as well as about $4 million associated with lower expected pass-through revenue. The positive impact of foreign currency fluctuations versus our prior outlook for revenue is just about $1 million given that the devaluation of [indiscernible] is offsetting the strengthening of the majority of our other currencies. Also, our revised outlook does not contemplate impacts from any of our pending transactions that have yet to close. 
Within our total revenue projections, we expect in the U.S. organic tenant billings growth of about 5.5% to 6% for the year. This reflects the steady demand environment similar to we have seen year-to-date and anticipate that acceleration in our growth rate in the second half of the year as a result of the more even spread of new business commencements compared to the prior year period. Internationally, we expect organic tenant billings growth of nearly 14% supported by especially strong trends in markets like Mexico and Nigeria and Uganda where new business commencement activity is incredibly strong. At a consolidated level, organic tenant billings growth is expected to be nearly 8%. Newly-acquired and build sites are expected to contribute to balance of our anticipated tenant billings growth for the year or just over 14%. This growth has resulted in the continued expansion of our base of noncancelable tenant lease revenue, which now on a consolidated basis stand at nearly $32 billion with an average remaining lease term of about 5.6 years. We're also raising the midpoint of our outlook for adjusted EBITDA by $15 million. This reflects cash SG&A as a percent of total revenue of right around 8%. Our increased adjusted EBITDA outlook is driven by an $8 million benefit associated with increased net straight-line, $17 million in FX favorability and about $6 million in outperformance in the underlying property business relative to our previous expectations. This is being partially offset by $7 million receivable reserve booked in Q2 and about $9 million in lower expected contribution from our services segment versus our prior outlook where the pipeline of project-based activity has slowed. Given that substantially all of our Nigerian OpEx and SG&A expenses are denominated in local currency and that over half of our revenues are denominated in U.S. dollars, the impact of the Nigerian devaluation that I referenced earlier to EBITDA is minimal. 
Finally, we're raising our outlook for consolidated AFFO by $15 million at the midpoint or about 0.6%. This is being driven primarily by the $7 million increase in cash EBITDA, just discussed, plus roughly $13 million due to lower net cash interest expense expectations. This increase of $20 million is being partially offset by about $5 million resulting from higher expectations for corporate capital expenditures, primarily associated with IT spending to support our global operations. Assuming an average diluted share count of 429 million shares, this implies consolidated AFFO per share of $5.69 at the midpoint, reflecting a per share growth rate of about 12%. 
Before we move on, I also like to note that factoring in the July month to date actual FX rates and holding current spot rates constant for the rest of the year would result in additional upside of about $33 million for property revenue, $18 million for adjusted EBITDA and $14 million for consolidated AFFO or about $0.03 per share relative to the midpoints of our current outlook.
Turning to Slide 11. We remain committed to our capital deployment strategy and continue to focus on our goal of simultaneously funding growth, returning cash to our stockholders and maintaining a strong balance sheet. To this end, we declared nearly $500 million in common and mandatory convertible preferred stock dividends, spent approximately $1.2 trillion [ph] on accretive acquisitions and deployed nearly $330 million in CapEx so far this year, which includes nearly $76 million spent on ground lease purchases. In fact, since 2011, we deployed over $500 million for ground lease purchases in the U.S. while increasing the percentage of towers online to we own or control for over 20 years from about 55% in 2011 to nearly 67% today and extending the average remaining term on our lease land from just under 22 years to nearly 25 years. This activity further secures our long-term recurring cash flows while generating margin improvement and enhancing the operating leverage of our business through land rent expense reduction. We expect to continue deploying capital for land purchases over the long term and are targeting to have 80% of our towers in the U.S. on land that is either owned or leased for more than 20 years by 2020. 
We believe that our disciplined capital allocation strategy will enable us to deliver the combination of growth and consolidated AFFO per share and consistent return of capital to stockholders through our REIT distributions and drive compelling total returns for many years to come. In 2016, this includes expected growth in our dividend subject of board approval of at least 20%. 
Turning to Slide 12. And in summary, we've enhanced our strategic positioning so far in 2016 by continuing to employ a comprehensive, multi-pronged strategy. First, we further diversified our international presence by acquiring a controlling stake in Viom Networks in India. We believe mobile networks there are poised for significant 4G investment in urban metros and for a continuing deployment of coverage and initial data services in the suburban and rural areas where over 2/3 of Indians live. Second, we've continued to drive operational excellence through our business while focusing on the integration of our recently acquired portfolios in several key markets. And third, we remain focused on strengthening our balance sheet through opportunistic refinancing and selected debt repayments. And fourth, we've simultaneously maintain strong growth in our common stock dividend. As a result, we are well positioned to finish this year strong, driving compelling growth in revenue, net income, adjusted EBITDA, consolidated AFFO while returning significant cash to our shareholders through our common stock dividend. This is all made possible by our unmatched global scale, experienced regional leadership teams and disciplined the capital allocation strategy, which we expect to remain consistent for the rest of this year and well into the future. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for some closing remarks before we take some Q&A. Jim?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning to everyone on the call. Today, similar to prior second quarter earnings calls, my comments will focus on American Tower's international operations. As you just heard, our Asia, EMEA and Latin America segments all generated a
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning to everyone on the call. Today, similar to prior second quarter earnings calls, my comments will focus on American Tower's international operations. As you just heard, our Asia, EMEA and Latin America segments all generated another strong quarter of operating results in Q2, once again serving as a turbocharger for our market-leading domestic business. 
Beginning with American Tower's first international investment in Mexico in 1999, we methodically expanded our geographic scope and scale based on a set of fundamental tenants. First, we recognized that the power of the tower business model that has first been developed in the United States should equally apply in additional countries that presented the right operating conditions. It is our experience that due to a number of common factors, the fundamental drivers of tower demand are consistent across our selected geographies. First, consumers everywhere have a huge appetite for mobile technology and service. And moreover, the underlying physics of radiowave propagation, usable spectrum bands and the 2G, 3G and 4G technology standards all apply globally. Plus, the network equipment on the OEMs, the handset manufacturers such as Apple and the chipset developers like QUALCOMM sell their products all over the world. Second, we understood from our U.S. experience that by buying towers for mobile operators, we can transform single-use, nonperforming cost center assets into high-performing, multiuse commercial real estate. Consequently, sale leaseback transactions for these assets provide an additional source of capital to mobile operators so they could more rapidly deploy their active networks and grow their core business. Again, since these commonsense economics apply across multiple countries, we've been able to pursue the same strategy successfully to date in Latin America, Africa, Germany and India. 
And third, we recognized that we did dramatically increase our growth opportunities while at the same time, benefiting from the diversity across various markets. Using standard portfolio theory, we expected that selectively diversifying our asset base, we could also reduce fluctuations in our cash flows, thereby delivering elevated, extended and more stable growth trajectory over a very long period of time. The results we have generated in our international markets confirm these principles. For example, on sites outside the U.S. that we've owned since the beginning of 2010, our U.S. dollar equivalent NOI yield as of the end of the second quarter was more than 30% as compared to around 18% on net vintage in the U.S. These results include both sites that we have acquired as part of our disciplined asset acquisition strategy and sites that we've constructed for our carrier customers. 
Meanwhile, international sites added between 2010 and 2013 are already yielding around 12% today, with sites added over the last few years already yielding an average of about 10%. While the yields on our younger international assets are solid, we believe the real opportunities to make value on these newer assets lies ahead. Our 2 decades of strength in the tower business have clearly illustrated that the longer we have assets on our portfolio, the more revenue and cash flow they generate. This is especially true outside the U.S. where most of our newly added sites have been single tenant at the time of acquisition or construction. Given that we have generated double-digit international organic tenant billings growth on average over the last 3 years and expect to continue to drive these types of solid growth rates going forward, we believe we have a tremendous opportunity to drive significant NOI yield accretion on our international assets over time. 
Consequently, we have positioned to the company for continuing long-term success with our combined domestic U.S. and global asset base. MIT researchers Erik Robison and Andrew McAfee have identified 3 key elements to building competitive advantage in the digital age: physical capital, intellectual capital and organizational capital. On all 3 of these dimensions, American Tower now has built a sustainable global competitive advantage in telecommunications real estate, which we believe would be difficult to replicate. First is our physical capital, the 140,000-plus towers in small cell systems that we've constructed and acquired, their high structural capacity, premier locations and existing and future cash flow generation potential. The depth, diversity and global reach of this physical capital are, in our view, unmatched. And we believe that replicating our portfolio while achieving similar economics in the future would be a very formidable task. 
Second is the intellectual capital we have cultivated at American Tower since the mid-1990s. The systems and processes that we've developed, refined and optimized to be able to support 10s of thousands of properties spanning in 5 continents, and it positions company further asset growth in the future. I actually believe that ATC is world-class in the most critical operational skills in this business, formulating highly complex master lease agreement tailored to our customers' needs, coupled with the ability to manage literally hundreds of thousands of individual tenant and ground leases every month. 
And third is the organizational capital that has been nurtured and developed at all levels in this company. I believe we have the most capable senior management team in the industry that have in turn built high-performance organizations in our key functions across all of our geographies. Our retention of highly skilled executives, management and employees have been excellent, resulting in an experienced workforce today. Additionally, as a recognized global leader, American Tower's brand enabled us to recruit outstanding talent to support the rapid growth of the business. We've also developed comprehensive training and development programs targeted to continually improve our capabilities and proprietary skills such as structural engineering and lease contracting.
So as a result of building our physical, intellectual, organizational capital methodically over the past 20 years, we've maintained the leadership position among fully independent tower companies in each of the leading 3 market democracies on the 5 most populous continents in the world while creating a cash flow engine that continues to gather momentum. With our unique and dynamic position in this telecommunications real estate business, we expect to provide an attractive combination of growth and yield to our investors for many, many years to come. 
Thank you for joining our call this morning, and operator, please open it up now for questions.

componenttext: I was wondering if we could dig a bit deeper into U.S. properties a bit here. As you mentioned, Tom, you're guiding factors in what I believe you characterize as anticipated acceleration in your business, while I realize given carrier-specific detail isn't where you may want to go, perhaps you can give us color on one initiatives you're seeing and how you think the trajectory of the business should turn over the next 12 months? Maybe you can provide us with some insight on what you're hearing from your conversations with carriers and whether you believe there's either a risk or perhaps middle ground going forward?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amir, this is Jim. Why don't I take the second part of your question, and Tom can go to more quantitative side after that. As you know and as we said, we do not comment on specific customer negotiations, discussions or their plans. But what we can do is p
componenttext: Amir, this is Jim. Why don't I take the second part of your question, and Tom can go to more quantitative side after that. As you know and as we said, we do not comment on specific customer negotiations, discussions or their plans. But what we can do is provide you facts for the Big 4 U.S. national carriers in aggregate, and these are average remaining term and domestic churn, excluding our nonnational customers. Now we can start to see the trend of the business as part is far of duration and falloff. So for 2016, our expected remaining term for the 4 nationals is 6.6 years, and the churn is only approximately 0.2%. So we feel very confident about the stability of our U.S. domestic sort of Big 4 asset base or revenue base right now. And the other piece of that is the escalator, which across the U.S. on average is still above 3%. So I'll turn it over to Tom.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Amir, I think kind of coupling to what Jim has just said. If you take a look at what our pipeline support, we've talked about this momentum kicking in, in the second half. And we also, as a result, see about 47% of our total organic business gene
componenttext: Yes, and Amir, I think kind of coupling to what Jim has just said. If you take a look at what our pipeline support, we've talked about this momentum kicking in, in the second half. And we also, as a result, see about 47% of our total organic business generated in the first half with 53% in the second half. So I think that, that also kind of reflects my remarks and Jim's remarks that we can continually see this growing pipeline of colocation amendments. In the United States, I think you're well aware that over the last 3 quarters, it's been a large piece of amendment activity continually to filling in and meeting that capacity. And so as we've always talked about, we see this amendment in colo activity in the form of sine waves. And so we fully believe that all the carriers are generating their own sine waves in terms of new business, grooming, colos, amendments. And I think, as I mentioned, we see a more momentum coming even to the second half of the year, which we think will position us well then for going into 2017.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I mean, overall, for the region, I think I mentioned in my remarks, I would say it's in that kind of 12% kind of range in that particular market. It's been ready steady. It's really interesting with all the issues that they have in the marketpl
componenttext: Yes, sure. I mean, overall, for the region, I think I mentioned in my remarks, I would say it's in that kind of 12% kind of range in that particular market. It's been ready steady. It's really interesting with all the issues that they have in the marketplace, we've seen quite steady performance this year. It's down from where it was last year, clearly. And in addition, as I mentioned, we took the additional reserve this particular quarter just from a total revenue perspective. But the level of activity in the market has actually been quite steady, and we expect to see that same level of activity for the balance of the year.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question from David Barden.
componenttext: And the next question from David Barden.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. Just maybe this is for you, Jim or Tom. Just following up on the early question. The T-Mobile and AT&T I think pretty explicitly gone out there and try to solicit alternatives for macrocell sites that have been compounding for maybe 10 or
componenttext: Two, if I could. Just maybe this is for you, Jim or Tom. Just following up on the early question. The T-Mobile and AT&T I think pretty explicitly gone out there and try to solicit alternatives for macrocell sites that have been compounding for maybe 10 or even 20 years, and there's a conceivably a window for economic substitution for new tower builds. Could you talk about what you see is the vulnerability of the AMT's domestic portfolio in terms of long-term leases that have compounded with terms of leases that are expiring with alternative sightings that might be nearby? It doesn't seem like it could be very big, but I'm wondering if you see if at all as a potential vulnerability at this stage? And then second, in India, obviously, party [indiscernible] has been talking about the potential for resetting leases pricing lower at the end of the term of some of their main shareholder leases. Obviously, with Viom, you're going to have a larger overlap with them. I was wondering if you could kind of talk about the outlook for market lease pricing in India going forward?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. It's Jim. What I would say about potential substitution anywhere for towers is that, just to remind you, you all know the functional inputs of the franchise value of the tower. And so first of all, any change of equipment from one tower to an
componenttext: Sure, David. It's Jim. What I would say about potential substitution anywhere for towers is that, just to remind you, you all know the functional inputs of the franchise value of the tower. And so first of all, any change of equipment from one tower to another one, assuming you could even build it nearby, is fairly costly for any operator, so that's something they have to put in their equation. Also, the longer the sites have been up, the more [indiscernible] beyond, et cetera, and more embedded it is on the network. So there are some network difficulties and economic cost to doing a switch. And as you know, the other part of the franchise value is that most municipalities try to manage the number of structures in their jurisdiction, and we'd take that into account. And then thirdly, we continually try to reach mutually beneficial arrangements with our customers that can ameliorate the impact of specific high-priced sites as far as the contract. So we'll continue to help them as we can in that way as well. So I do think that having some metrics for you to track over the years will be the useful way to keep track of all this, and that's why I wanted to put out to you what are our average remaining term is for the Big 4 in aggregate and also what the churn rate for the nonnationals sort of assets in the Big 4, excluding the nonnational the assets of the Big 4 are. And I just said, it was 0.2%. So again, so far, with the industry conditions we expect to continue, it's a very, very low as far as actual turn off. But we'll keep providing those metrics as we move forward in time. Secondly, on the Indian market, it's a critical difference to be truly independent provider of [indiscernible] and any country versus a captive provider of siding, in other words, you're a subsidiary or affiliate of the mobile operator itself. Those contracts, I don't want to speak to, but I can speak to our contracts. With all mobile operators in India as being market-based and, therefore, arm's-length and certain provisions that may apply at captive contracts may or may not apply to ours. I just -- I guess I would set the foundation there because then we don't talk about specific contracts or discussions or negotiations in any of our markets. So that's I think a fundamental way to look at it is how do independence yield with mobile operators and how the captive is doing with mobile operators. And again, you can track our metrics over time in that regard.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just was hoping that maybe you could provide a little color, Tom, in sort of understanding the change in the organic growth metrics that you delivered and help sort of bridge the gap. I know when I look at the first quarter numbers, the total organic gr
componenttext: I just was hoping that maybe you could provide a little color, Tom, in sort of understanding the change in the organic growth metrics that you delivered and help sort of bridge the gap. I know when I look at the first quarter numbers, the total organic growth was 7.9. This quarter, it's 7. And I know that those may actually be very close to the same number just based on differences in calculations, and so can you give us a little bit of a look onto the hood, it might be helpful.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the definitions which are on the release and the back of the slides that we have here. But I mean, the fundamental difference in the organic. We're really trying to, as we talked about last quarter, really trying to give a true run rate, a re
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the definitions which are on the release and the back of the slides that we have here. But I mean, the fundamental difference in the organic. We're really trying to, as we talked about last quarter, really trying to give a true run rate, a recurring run rate of build revenue. And so the tenant billings, if you will, that's recurring revenue that is constantly being invoiced to customers. Outside of that, we think it gets you to the reported or things like pass-through and straight-line and all those other elements, which had a lot of volatility from quarter to quarter. And then on an organic basis, what we really trying to do is again give you that recurring revenue that we have from colos amendments, plus escalators, less churn to give you a true view in terms of what the additional activity is happening on all of the sites that we have. So if you take a look at, for example, the U.S. in this particular quarter, if you exclude again the decommissioning revenue, which again was kind of again that volatile, now you're right in for the U.S., it's in the mid-5s, right about that 5.5% and versus the organic number that we talked about now under the tenant billings methodology of 5.6%. So it's very, very similar in terms of what the rates were that we talked about last quarter and that we would see in Q2. Similarly, for international, if you looked at the core organic growth, we're talking about 13.7% on the tenant billings organic basis, which is the number we just referred to. On the international side, again, if you backed up the impact of oil, we'll be right at 13.5%. So again, what we're trying to do is, we're trying to just reflect what that real run rate recurring billings stream would be. So very, very similar, just a couple of nuances in terms of the differences between the organic core growth and the tenant billings, the real differences being that decommissioning revenue in the U.S., which would be the kind of the major element to reconcile it to and the reserve that we took on the oi or on the Brazilian business in Brazil.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, you talked about the capital allocation portion a couple of times. I remember when you became a REIT, you set a fairly low payout, reflecting the part of NOLs. Can you just update us on the NOL stratosphere for payout? And how should we take about di
componenttext: Tom, you talked about the capital allocation portion a couple of times. I remember when you became a REIT, you set a fairly low payout, reflecting the part of NOLs. Can you just update us on the NOL stratosphere for payout? And how should we take about dividend growth at some point? The 20% number is going to come down to more match your growth, so what should be thinking about there? And then there's been a lot of comments over last little while about various outdoor small cell strategies and municipal pushback and so forth. I just wanted to get your perspective on that market at this point.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll take of the first part, and Jim take the second part. On the dividend, you're absolutely accurate, we started up being a REIT. We add a sizable amount of NOLs at that time, and we've utilized of those largely over the last 3, 4 years. And so
componenttext: Sure. So I'll take of the first part, and Jim take the second part. On the dividend, you're absolutely accurate, we started up being a REIT. We add a sizable amount of NOLs at that time, and we've utilized of those largely over the last 3, 4 years. And so we have $50 million of NOLs or so. And as a result, our payout has been down in the 30%, 35% range, which is where it exists today. We fully expect that as a result no longer having those NOLs and having assets that are further being depreciated that over the next couple of years, we would start to see payouts in the 45% to 50% range of AFFO. So there's no doubt that we're going to be paying a large piece of that AFFO, clearly, as a result of that having those NOLs available.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With that value to keep the 20% for a couple of years?
componenttext: With that value to keep the 20% for a couple of years?

componenttextpreview: Well, no, again, it's all subject to board approval. Really, looking at 2000 [ph] we'll take it a year at a time, but we would expect that the -- I would expect that, that growth rate would be able to continue for the next, yes, couple of years.
componenttext: Well, no, again, it's all subject to board approval. Really, looking at 2000 [ph] we'll take it a year at a time, but we would expect that the -- I would expect that, that growth rate would be able to continue for the next, yes, couple of years.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simon, it's Jim. Regarding our small cell strategy overall, we've chosen to focus on indoor DAS systems and ultimately small cell systems as where we think the best returns have been can be attained. We're also actively exploring innovative ways to achiev
componenttext: Simon, it's Jim. Regarding our small cell strategy overall, we've chosen to focus on indoor DAS systems and ultimately small cell systems as where we think the best returns have been can be attained. We're also actively exploring innovative ways to achieve tower-like returns on other what we call macro supplement type of assets, and that could be outdoor, small cells and other technologies that can better serve the high density I think the classic tower the macro tower is going to serve its purpose for the foreseeable future because we are really the business macro tower providing mobile service and suburban largely and corridor, transportation corridor and rural environment. And where a lot of small cell demand is coming, as you hear from the carriers and others, is in the really high-density locations such as urban centers where towers don't have a role, much of a role to play anyhow. So this could be a complementary business for us if we could figure out how to scale it, but importantly, how to scale it with tower-like returns. And that's what we're really aggressively exploring today, although I have to admit, we haven't solve the problem quite yet. And I think already you're seeing the issue with urban small cell deployments is have a big role in what gets built on their jurisdiction and how it gets built and if it's shared or single use. And so there are some municipal debates on some of the projects going on by all of the industry today. And we want to continue to work out all those issues as time goes on and figure out that if we can get tower-like returns from these kinds of projects. So it's going to be a long-cycle approach. 5G, even the standard won't be settled probably 2019, 2020, and they'll start being deployed in some of these dense venues. In the meantime, 4G that go to technology for at least the next 4 or 5 years and then another 5 to 10 beyond as you migrate to 5G. So I think we have some time to figure this out, but it is a knotty problem and we hope we can figure out to get out to get tower-like returns on the assets some day.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, Rick, what we're guiding to is consolidated AFFO has been -- our guidance has been based on. So that's what 2016, based upon what a numbers that I just talked about a few minutes ago, that's what our outlook is based on.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, can you give us a little bit more color on India kind of what's going on from a technology perspective, volume perspective and pricing? It sounds like your pricing is kind of what below the captive kind of tower companies. Any color there would be gr
componenttext: Jim, can you give us a little bit more color on India kind of what's going on from a technology perspective, volume perspective and pricing? It sounds like your pricing is kind of what below the captive kind of tower companies. Any color there would be great.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tim. First of all, I'll speak to technology and volume pricing last. But the technology deployment in India is regarding right timing. We got a new entrant just the customer watching a national 4G network, which is going to, in some ways, leapfrog w
componenttext: Sure, Tim. First of all, I'll speak to technology and volume pricing last. But the technology deployment in India is regarding right timing. We got a new entrant just the customer watching a national 4G network, which is going to, in some ways, leapfrog what's available today and also motivating the other market theaters to invest in 4G as well. So we see, as Tom said, sort of an up-cycle in technology investment in India at a scale that may have never been done before given the population in that country. Relatively over a few years, which has positioned us I think relatively well on the Viom acquisition as we kind of talk it now to ride that wave of technology investment. And there's some great companies involved. These are significant multinationals like Vodafone as well as 4G Airtel, as I mentioned, Reliance Industries, there's also Reliance Telecom. There's going to be some real competition from really moving quickly through 3G into 4G sort of technology territory. And as we all know, densification and equipment goes up as you go into the tire technology stack. So we're very optimistic about the technology kind of road map for the country. As far as volume, what was interesting about the Viom merger with ATC India was that our major customers happened to be the partners in this. So Airtel, Vodafone, Idea are very large customers of ATC, proportionately not as much actually of Viom where, of course, Tata was the core customer there. So we've got a complementary opportunity when we put these 2 assets together to drive volume in both directions, which I think is really going to be great for leasing for our market again over the next number of years and will play out. And then finally, pricing, I think it's miscasting that our pricing was lower than the [indiscernible] we tend to drive as high as we can without being tethered to the parent, and that's been I think a fairly successful endeavor. But we do have this the in the context of the overall market and certainly don't overprice, but I would say that we're probably on the upper end of pricing given our independence and the quality of our assets and finally, our ability to do construction jobs quickly in a difficult place.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

It's going to be more of a the outsource model I think with our Viom acquisition. And actually, increasing independence of the captives over some period of time as they go public or float more shares and if get more mature will probably also constructive to that.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've had your perch in Europe for quite a while, and we've been seeing tower M&A activity increasing. It doesn't seem like you've been very involved. I'd love to understand why you haven't been very active. Are there any specific reasons why European to
componenttext: You've had your perch in Europe for quite a while, and we've been seeing tower M&A activity increasing. It doesn't seem like you've been very involved. I'd love to understand why you haven't been very active. Are there any specific reasons why European tower assets haven't been a feeling to you?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's Jim. we've been extremely active in business development in Europe for probably 10 years. What hasn't occurred is that asset trading price meeting our investment criteria. It happened once in Germany where we do have a really great base with th
componenttext: Sure, it's Jim. we've been extremely active in business development in Europe for probably 10 years. What hasn't occurred is that asset trading price meeting our investment criteria. It happened once in Germany where we do have a really great base with the KPN assets in part of Telefónica. So we think we're firmly positioned with a great beachhead in the continent and continually strive to work negotiations so that we can get our investment criteria met and invest more in the region. And so far, that combination we have not been able to secure. And it mainly has to do with asset pricing and the characteristics of the market and the returns that go get. So we are poised, just like with small cells, aggressively pursue assets that meet our investment criteria. If we can locate or determine those, we will act quickly and decisively. When we don't, we will avoid investing in what we consider the time to be lower-return opportunities, frankly.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about as you look at the industry in more small cell activity whether you're in building DAS or outside small building DAS, there seem to be more upfront revenue component, which then converts into deferred revenues and call it prepaid rent. And so how do you look at this category in terms of the impact to revenue, how it impacts cash flow and how would you think about the valuation of assets and the return on your assets between the cash versus some of the noncash contribution in the income statement?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On a pure ROI basis, Michael, in terms of economics whether a project make sense or not, capital coming in from a customer is clearly going to have impact in terms of what their ROI is ultimately going to be, right? I mean, it's just discounted cash flow.
componenttext: On a pure ROI basis, Michael, in terms of economics whether a project make sense or not, capital coming in from a customer is clearly going to have impact in terms of what their ROI is ultimately going to be, right? I mean, it's just discounted cash flow. From a P&L perspective, I think you can see from the release and from our supplemental that you can you recognize just how that revenue is recognized, and it's being recognized over the balance of the lease. And you can see that even on the quarter-over-quarter basis, I think the number is around $20 million, almost identical to what it was same quarter of last year. So that number continues to be fairly consistent on an annual basis. There's not a lot of volatility, not a lot of growth, not a lot of decline in it. As we continue to invest in those types of systems, we're actually getting capital contributions. So I look at it from 2 perspectives. One is just on the ROI, whether the transaction make sense, it just goes into the Math to determine whether a particular project meets our internal thresholds to be able to move forward with it. And then the recognition of that particular revenue is then over the remaining balance of the lease term.

componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the American Tower Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Leah Stearns, Senior Vice President, Treasurer and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning to discuss our second quarter earnings.Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows: First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial resul
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning to discuss our second quarter earnings.
Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows: First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial results. Next, Tom Bartlett, our Executive Vice President and CFO, will provide a more detailed review of our financial and operational performance for the second quarter 2016 as well as our full year outlook for the full year of 2016. And finally, Jim Taiclet, our Chairman, President and CEO, will provide a brief update on our international business and strategy. After these comments, we will open up the call for your questions.
Before I begin, I would like to remind you that this call will contain forward-looking statements that involve a number of risks and uncertainties. Examples of these statements include those regarding our expectations for future growth, including our 2016 outlook, foreign currency exchange rates and future operating performance; technology and industry trends; and any other statements regarding matters that are not historical facts.
You should be aware that certain factors may affect us in the future and could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in these forward-looking statements. Such factors include the risk factories set forth in this morning's press release, those set forth in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and in other filings we make with the SEC. We urge you to consider these factors and remind you that we undertake no obligation to update the information contained in this call to reflect subsequent events or circumstances.
In addition to this morning's press release, we have posted a presentation, which we will reference throughout our prepared remarks, under the Investor Relations tab on our website. I'd like to note that we have updated the name of our run rate revenue metric to tenant billing. As we highlighted for you last quarter when we introduced this metric, it reflects the current tenant billings, which are generated by our global portfolio of communications real estate.
In addition, in response to recently issued disclosure guidance by the SEC, after today, we will no longer reference our core growth metrics.
So with that, please turn to Slide 4 of the presentation, which highlights our financial results. During the quarter, property revenue grew approximately 24% to nearly $1.43 billion. Total revenues grew approximately 23% to over $1.44 billion, and net income attributable to American Tower Corporation common stockholders increased by over 24% to $161 million or $0.37 per diluted common share.
Our effective tax rate during the quarter was over 18% and included an income tax reserve related to our Viom transaction. For the year, we now expect our effective tax rate will be in the low double digit. Adjusted EBITDA during the quarter grew 14% to approximately $869 million and consolidated adjusted funds from operations increased by over 10% to approximately $592 million or $1.38 per diluted share.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. As you can see from the results we released this morning, we had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and good margin performance across our global asset base. We also declared a common stock divid
componenttext:
Thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. As you can see from the results we released this morning, we had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and good margin performance across our global asset base. We also declared a common stock dividend of $0.53 a share, which was up over 20% from the prior year period. And given the close of our Viom transaction in late April, our teams in India are now working hard to seamlessly integrate more than 42,000 towers we added to our portfolio with that acquisition.
If you please turn to Slide 6, let's take a look at our quarterly results. You can see that we generated strong performance with total reported property revenue growth of about 24%. This included total tenant billings growth of over 23%, of which about 8% was organic, driven by consistent demand levels throughout our global footprint.
Our total property revenue growth this quarter included a negative 60 basis point impact from a $7 million revenue reserve related to receivables associated with a tenant in Brazil, which were outstanding at the time of their judicial reorganization filing. Based on our prior experiences with carrier bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings, we expect to pursue the full amount owed to us. Additionally, I would note that this tenant has resumed payments to us for amounts owed subsequent to their judicial reorganization filing date.
Our U.S. property segment generated total reported revenue growth of about 3%, including a negative 1.4% impact from straight-line revenue account recognition. We did not book any decommissioning revenue this quarter as compared to about $8 million recorded in Q2 of last year and $31 million or so booked in Q1. This negatively impacted our U.S. property revenue growth by an additional 1.1%.
U.S. organic tenant billings growth for the quarter was 5.6%, which again reflects organic build recurring revenue and was right in line with our expectations. Demand trends in the U.S. remain very steady with carriers actively spending to augment their 4G networks. Our international markets generated organic tenant billings growth of 13.7% or 800 basis points higher than that of the U.S. Escalators associated with rising local market inflation contributed about 7% to that growth, while organic new business commencements were even larger component of the growth at about 7.6%. These were partially offset by some churn of just over 1%.
There was broad strength across our international property segments with all 3 posting double-digit organic tenant billings growth rates, including 12% in Latin America, 20% in EMEA and over 10% in Asia. Our multinational tenant base in these markets continue to make significant investments in their networks as more and more of their customers gain access to advance headsets -- handsets at lower per unit cost and begin to use exponentially more data on those handsets. The benefits of the geographic tenant and technological diversification built into our business model continues to be evidenced by the strong growth rates we are generating in our international markets.
Finally, on a total property basis, the day one revenue associated with the nearly 57,000 sites we have added since the second quarter of last year, including the Viom, Airtel Nigeria and TIM Brazil portfolios and roughly 3,400 new builds contributed another 15% to our total tenant billings growth in Q2, bringing the total growth to the nearly 23%. Our newbuild program remains active, and we constructed nearly 400 towers this quarter with an average day one NOI yield of over 10%.
Moving on to Slide 7. The combination of solid revenue growth and tight cost controls led to strong margin performance across our business. Gross margin in the quarter remained strong at over 68% despite a negative impact of over 10% from pass-through and a negative impact of 4.6% due to the addition of new sites, which have lower initial tenancies and margins. This was supported by strong conversion of revenue to gross margin on legacy sites during the quarter, while our reported conversion of revenue to gross margin was around 49% as a result of the previously mentioned negative impacts of pass-through revenue and lower-tenancy new sites, which on a combined basis negatively impacted the reported conversion ratio by about 50%. Our ability to convert revenue to gross margin on our pre-existing sites remain strong and in line with historical norms of well over 90%.
Finally, our adjusted EBITDA margin was about 60% for the quarter, which includes a negative impact from pass-through of about 9%. This also includes about 4.3% of margin dilution associated with new sites brought into the portfolio since the start of the second quarter of last year, including Viom. Cash SG&A as a percentage of revenue was about 8.1% in the quarter and is expected to be right around 8% for the full year.
Our adjusted EBITDA and consolidated AFFO growth in the quarter is detailed on Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA grew 14% to about $869 million as a result of our top line growth, coupled with the diligent operational expense management. Our solid adjusted EBITDA performance drove growth in consolidated AFFO as it's slightly lower-than-expected capital improvement and capital expenditures. This led to growth in consolidated AFFO of over 10% and growth in consolidated AFFO per share of nearly 10%. The global operational efficiency initiatives that we put into place continue to result in strong profitability for the business.
Moving on to Slide 9. We remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet with financial policies designed to support this objective by managing risk across the capital structure in support of our investment-grade rating. In the second quarter, we pursued several financing initiatives directly supporting these policies. First, we raised $1 billion in 10-year senior unsecured notes at a historically low coupon rate for ATC of 3.375%. This opportunistic transaction increased our liquidity and turned out a significant portion of our floating rate debt.
Next, we assume nearly $800 million of rupee-denominated debt in connection with our acquisition of a majority interest in Viom. We immediately commenced a multiyear process to refinance the existing loans locally at more attractive rates than the initial 11% average coupon. They have already decreased the average cost to about 10.3%. These actions highlight our excellent access to diversify funding sources, including the investment-grade volume market as well as an ability to maintain a substantial base of liquidity to support our solid balance sheet. As a result, as of the end of the second quarter, our net leverage ratio was 5.3x net debt to annualized Q2 adjusted EBITDA with liquidity of over $3 billion. We continue to expect to end the year at 5x net debt or below. And longer term, our target leverage range remains between 3 and 5x.
Turning to Slide 10. Given our solid performance in the first half of the year, continued improvements in foreign currency exchange rate forecast and underlying trends that are consistent with our previous assumptions, we are raising our full year guidance for 2016. At the midpoint of our outlook, we're increasing our expectations for property revenue by $10 million or about 0.2%, resulting in projected reported growth of 21% or so. The increase is being driven by a $14 million increase in straight-line revenue and $7 million in favorability in organic tenant billing revenue across our property segment. This favorability is being partially offset by about $7 million from the reserve book this quarter in Brazil as well as about $4 million associated with lower expected pass-through revenue.
The positive impact of foreign currency fluctuations versus our prior outlook for revenue is just about $1 million, given that the devaluation of naira is offsetting the strengthening of the majority of our other currencies. Also, our revised outlook does not contemplate impacts from any of our pending transactions that have yet to close.
Within our total revenue projections, we expect in the U.S. organic tenant billings growth of about 5.5% to 6% for the year. This reflects a steady demand environment similar to what we have seen year-to-date and anticipated acceleration in our growth rate in the second half of the year as a result of a more even spread of new business commencements compared to the prior year period.
Internationally, we expect organic tenant billings growth of nearly 14% supported by especially strong trends in markets like Mexico, Nigeria and Uganda, where new business commencement activity is incredibly strong. At consolidated level, organic tenant billings growth is expected to be nearly 8%. Newly-acquired and build sites are expected to contribute the balance of our anticipated tenant billings growth for the year or just over 14%. This growth has resulted in the continued expansion of our base of noncancelable tenant lease revenue, which now on a consolidated basis stand at nearly $32 billion, with an average remaining lease term of about 5.6 years.
We're also raising the midpoint of our outlook for adjusted EBITDA by $15 million. This reflects cash SG&A as a percent of total revenue of right around 8%. Our increased adjusted EBITDA outlook is driven by an $8 million benefit associated with increased net straight-line, $17 million in FX favorability and about $6 million in outperformance in the underlying property business relative to our previous expectations. This is being partially offset by $7 million receivable reserve booked in Q2 and about $9 million in lower expected contribution from our services segment versus our prior outlook, where the pipeline of project-based activity has slowed. Given that substantially all of our Nigerian OpEx and SG&A expenses are denominated in local currency and that over half of our revenues are denominated in U.S. dollars, the impact of the Nigerian Naira devaluation I referenced earlier to EBITDA is minimal.
Finally, we're raising our outlook for consolidated AFFO by $15 million at the midpoint or about 0.6%. This is being driven primarily by the $7 million increase in cash EBITDA, just discussed, plus roughly $13 million due to lower net cash interest expense expectations. This increase of $20 million is being partially offset by about $5 million resulting from higher expectations for corporate capital expenditures, primarily associated with IT spending to support our global operations. Assuming an average diluted share count of 429 million shares, this implies consolidated AFFO per share of $5.69 at the midpoint, reflecting a per share growth rate of about 12%.
Before we move on, I'd also like to note that factoring in the July month to date actual FX rates and holding current spot rates constant for the rest of the year would result in additional upside of about $33 million for property revenue, $18 million for adjusted EBITDA and $14 million for consolidated AFFO or about $0.03 per share relative to the midpoints of our current outlook.
Turning to Slide 11. We remain committed to our capital deployment strategy and continue to focus on our goal of simultaneously funding growth, returning cash to our stockholders and maintaining a strong balance sheet. To this end, we've declared nearly $500 million in common and mandatory convertible preferred stock dividends, spent approximately $1.2 billion on accretive acquisitions and deployed nearly $330 million in CapEx so far this year, which includes nearly $76 million spent on ground lease purchases. In fact, since 2011, we've deployed over $500 million for ground lease purchases in the U.S., while increasing the percentage of towers on land we owned or control for over 20 years from about 55% in 2011 to nearly 67% today and extending the average remaining term on our lease land from just under 22 years to nearly 25 years. This activity further secures our long-term recurring cash flows while generating margin improvement and enhancing the operating leverage of our business through land rent expense reduction. We expect to continue deploying capital for land purchases over the long term and are targeting to have 80% of our towers in the U.S. on land that is either owned or leased for more than 20 years by 2020.
We believe that our disciplined capital allocation strategy will enable us to deliver the combination of growth in consolidated AFFO per share and consistent return of capital to stockholders through our REIT distributions and drive compelling total returns for many years to come. In 2016, this includes expected growth in our dividend subject to board approval of at least 20%.
Turning to Slide 12. And in summary, we've enhanced our strategic positioning so far in 2016 by continuing to employ a comprehensive, multi-pronged strategy. First, we further diversified our international presence by acquiring a controlling stake in Viom Networks in India. We believe mobile networks there poised for significant 4G investments in urban metros and for continuing deployment of coverage and initial data services in the suburban and rural areas where over 2/3 of Indians live.
Second, we've continued to drive operational excellence through our business while focusing on the integration of our recently acquired portfolios in several key markets. And third, we remained focused on strengthening our balance sheet through opportunistic refinancing and selected debt repayments. And fourth, we've simultaneously maintained strong growth in our common stock dividend. As a result, we're well positioned to finish this year strong, driving compelling growth in revenue, net income, adjusted EBITDA, consolidated AFFO while returning significant cash to our shareholders through our common stock dividend. This is all made possible by our unmatched global scale, experienced regional leadership teams and disciplined capital allocation strategy, which we expect to remain consistent for the rest of this year and well into the future.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for some closing remarks before we take some Q&A. Jim?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning to everyone on the call. Today, similar to prior second quarter earnings calls, my comments will focus on American Tower's international operations. As you just heard, our Asia, EMEA and Latin America segments all generated a
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning to everyone on the call. Today, similar to prior second quarter earnings calls, my comments will focus on American Tower's international operations. As you just heard, our Asia, EMEA and Latin America segments all generated another strong quarter of operating results in Q2, once again serving as a turbocharger for our market-leading domestic business.
Beginning with American Tower's first international investment in Mexico in 1999, we methodically expanded our geographic scope and scale based on the set of fundamental tenants. First, we recognized that the power of the tower business model that has first been developed in the United States should equally apply in additional countries that presented the right operating conditions. It is our experience that due to a number of common factors, the fundamental drivers of tower demand are consistent across our selected geographies.
First, consumers everywhere have a huge appetite for mobile technology and service. And moreover, the underlying physics of radio wave propagation, usable spectrum bands and the 2G, 3G and 4G technology standards all apply globally. Plus, the network equipment on the OEMs, the handset manufacturers such as Apple and the chipset developers like QUALCOMM sell their products all over the world.
Second, we understood from our U.S. experience that by buying towers from mobile operators, we could transform single-use, nonperforming cost-center assets into high-performing, multiuse commercial real estate. Consequently, sale leaseback transactions for these assets provide an additional source of capital to mobile operators, so they could more rapidly deploy their active networks and grow their core business. Again, since these common sense economics apply across multiple countries, we've been able to pursue the same strategy successfully to date in Latin America, Africa, Germany and India.
And third, we recognized that we did dramatically increase our growth opportunities while at the same time, benefiting from the diversity across various markets. Using standard portfolio theory, we expected that by selectively diversifying our asset base, we could also reduce fluctuations in our cash flows, thereby delivering an elevated, extended and more stable growth trajectory over a very long period of time.
The results we have generated in our international markets confirm these principles. For example, on sites outside the U.S. that we've owned since the beginning of 2010, our U.S. dollar equivalent NOI yield as of the end of the second quarter was more than 30% as compared to around 18% on net vintage in the U.S. These results include both sites that we have acquired as part of our disciplined asset acquisition strategy and sites that we've constructed for our carrier customers.
Meanwhile, international sites added between 2010 and 2013 are already yielding around 12% today, with sites added over the last few years already yielding an average of about 10%. While the yields on our younger international assets are solid, we believe the real opportunities to make value on these newer assets lies ahead.
Our 2 decades of experience in the tower business have clearly illustrated that the longer we have assets in our portfolio, the more revenue and cash flow they generate. This is especially true outside the U.S., where most of our newly added sites have been single tenant at the time of acquisition or construction. Given that we have generated double-digit international organic tenant billings growth on average over the last 3 years and expect to continue to drive these types of solid growth rates going forward, we believe we have a tremendous opportunity to drive significant NOI yield accretion on our international assets over time.
Consequently, we have positioned the company for continuing long-term success with our combined domestic U.S. and global asset base. MIT researchers, Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee have identified 3 key elements to building competitive advantage in the digital age: physical capital, intellectual capital and organizational capital. On all 3 of these dimensions, American Tower now has built a sustainable global competitive advantage in telecommunications real estate, which we believe would be difficult to replicate.
First is our physical capital. The 140,000-plus towers in small cell systems that we've constructed and acquired. Their high structural capacity, premier locations and existing and future cash flow generation potential. The depth, diversity and global reach of this physical capital are, in our view, unmatched. And we believe that replicating our portfolio while achieving similar economics in the future would be a very formidable task.
Second is the intellectual capital we have cultivated at American Tower since the mid-1990s. The systems and processes that we've developed, refined and optimized to be able to support tens of thousands of properties spanning in 5 continents, and it positions the company for further asset growth in the future. I actually believe that ATC is world-class in the most critical operational skills in this business, formulating highly complex master lease agreement tailored to our customers' needs, coupled with the ability to manage literally hundreds of thousands of individual tenant and ground leases every month.
And third is the organizational capital though that has been nurtured and developed at all levels in this company. I believe we have the most capable senior management team in the industry that have in turn built high-performance organizations in our key functions across all of our geographies. Our retention of highly skilled executives, managers and employees has been excellent, resulting in an experienced workforce today. Additionally, as a recognized global leader, American Tower's brand enables us to recruit outstanding talent to support the rapid growth of the business. We've also developed comprehensive training and development programs targeted to continually improve our capabilities and proprietary skills such as structural engineering and lease contracting.
So as a result of building our physical, intellectual and organizational capital methodically over the past 20 years, we've obtained a leadership position among fully independent tower companies in each of the leading 3-market democracies on the 5 most populous continents in the world, while creating a cash flow engine that continues to gather momentum. With our unique and dynamic position in this telecommunications real estate business, we expect to provide an attractive combination of growth and yield to our investors for many, many years to come.
Thank you for joining our call this morning, and operator, please open it up now for questions.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
