headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the American Tower Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Ms. Leah Stearns. Please go a
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the American Tower Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Ms. Leah Stearns. Please go ahead.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thank you for joining American Tower's third quarter earnings conference call. Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows: First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial results. Next, Tom Bartlett, our
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thank you for joining American Tower's third quarter earnings conference call. Our agenda for this morning's call will be as follows: First, I will provide some brief highlights from our financial results. Next, Tom Bartlett, our Executive Vice President and CFO, will provide a more detailed review of our financial and operational performance for the third quarter as well as our full year outlook for 2016. And finally, Jim Taiclet, our Chairman, President and CEO, will provide a brief update on technology trends and how they impact our business and strategy. After these comments, we will open up the call for your questions. 
Before I begin, I would like to remind you that this call will contain forward-looking statements that involve a number of risks and uncertainties. Examples of these statements include those regarding our expectations for future growth, including our 2016 outlook, foreign currency exchange rates, dividend growth, leverage and future operating performance as well as technology and industry trends and any other statements regarding matters that are not historical facts. You should be aware that certain factors may affect us in the future and could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in these forward-looking statements. Such factors include the risk factors set forth in this morning's press release, those set forth in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and in other filings we make with the SEC. We urge you to consider these factors and remind you that we undertake no obligation to update the information contained in this call to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. 
In addition to this morning's press release, we have posted a presentation, which we will reference throughout our prepared remarks, under the Investor Relations tab on our website. 
So turning to Slide 4 of our presentation, I'll provide a few highlights from the third quarter. During the quarter, total property revenue grew approximately 24% to nearly $1.5 billion. Total revenue grew approximately 22% to over $1.51 billion, and net income attributable to American Tower Corporation common stockholders increased by approximately 212% to $238 million or $0.55 per diluted common share. Further, adjusted EBITDA grew by more than 17% to approximately $915 million, and consolidated adjusted funds from operations increased by nearly 15% to approximately $641 million or $1.49 per diluted share. 
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. We had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and margin performance across our global asset base, in fact achieving record levels of new business commencements in the quarter. Once again, we
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Leah. Good morning, everyone. We had another quarter of strong organic tenant billings growth and margin performance across our global asset base, in fact achieving record levels of new business commencements in the quarter. 
Once again, we achieved double-digit growth rates across all of our key metrics. During the period, we declared a common stock dividend of $0.55 per share, which, for 2016, we are targeting to grow over 20% from the prior year. 
Simultaneously, we continued to diligently integrate the Viom assets while focusing on driving organic growth and scaling our business worldwide. We also achieved our year-end leverage target about 3 months ahead of schedule. 
If you please turn to Slide 6, let's take a look at our quarterly results. Total reported property revenue growth was nearly 24%. This included totaled 10 billings growth of over 21%, of which about 8% was organic, driven by consistent wireless customer demand for our real estate throughout our global footprint. As I mentioned, organic commenced new business in the quarter was at record levels, about 23% higher than the Q3 of last year, split almost evenly between our U.S. and international businesses. Our U.S. Property segment revenue growth was about 3.6% factoring in a negative 1.7% impact from straight line revenue recognition. In addition, we've booked about $0.5 million in decommissioning revenue this quarter, as compared to about $4 million recorded in Q3 of last year, resulting in an additional 50 basis point negative impact to the growth rate. For the quarter, U.S. organic tenant billings growth was right in line with our expectations at 5.7%, reflecting a slight acceleration from Q2. Volume growth from co-locations and amendments contributed about 4.4%, while pricing escalators contributed 2.8% and other run rate items contributed about 30 basis points. This was partially offset by churn of about 1.8%, of which the vast majority was associated with smaller, non-big 4 tenants. And as we disclosed last quarter, operational churn from the big 4 wireless carriers, what we call core networks in the U.S., which is defined as excluding activity on the former network, has remained at about 30 basis points. Demand trends in the U.S. remained steady with carriers actively spending to augment the coverage and capacity of their 4G networks. 
Our international organic tenant billings growth was 13%, about 725 basis points higher than that of the U.S. While pricing escalators, driven by local CPI indices contributed about 7% of that growth. Volumes from co-locations and amendments were an even larger component at about 7.3%. Other run rate items contributed an additional 40 basis points. These all were partially offset by churn of about 1.6%. There was broad strength across our international property segment, with all 3 achieving double-digit organic organic tenant billings growth rates for the sixth quarter in a row. Organic tenant billings growth was almost 14% in Latin America, 12% in EMEA and over 11% in Asia. Our large multinational tenants in all these markets continue to make significant investments in their networks as more and more of their customers gain access to affordable, advanced headsets and begin to use significantly more data on those handsets. And these network investments appeared to be catalyzing incremental usage as the mobile experience gets better and better. For example, a carrier deploying a new greenfield 4G wireless broadband network in India has reported that its customers on average are already using well over 1 gig of data per day on that network. Along with trends like this, we expect the geographic tenant and technological diversification built into our business model to continue to drive strong growth rates for our international portfolio. Further, day 1 revenue associated with the nearly 46,000 sites we've added since the third quarter of last year, which includes the Viom portfolio and about 2,100 new builds, contributed another 13% to our global tenant billings growth in Q3. Our new build program remains active, and we constructed over 350 towers globally this quarter. While this level of build activity was a bit lower than historical levels, we would expect this trend to reverse and build activity to pick up again in Q4. Our newly build sites average an NOI yield of over 10% this quarter on a consolidated basis. 
Moving on to Slide 7. Gross margin in the quarter was nearly 68%, which was negatively impacted by past-due revenue and the addition of nearly 46,000 new lower initial margin sites. In the quarter, adjusting for the impact of past due, we converted more than 90% of revenue to gross margin on sites that we've owned for more than a year. This strong conversion performance generated rising NOI yields across our portfolio. The average NOI yield on international sites built to require up to including 2009, for example, rose to 32% while the NOI yield on-site data between 2010 and 2013 improved to 13%. And even on sites added in 2014 and later, including Viom, NOI yields are rising, improving sequentially to about 10%.  We think we have a tremendous opportunity to increase these NOI yields over time, particularly on our younger assets. 
Finally, our adjusted EBITDA margin was about 60.4% for the quarter, which was similarly impacted by pass-through in new sites. 
Cash, SG&A as a percentage of revenue, declined 7.4% in the quarter and is expected to be under 8% for the full year. Our adjusted EBITDA consolidated AFFO growth in the quarter is detailed in Slide 8. 
Adjusted EBITDA grew over 17% to approximately $915 million, and consolidated AFFO grew by nearly 15%, driven by combination of a solid adjusted EBITDA growth and expansion and seasonally lower-than-expected capital improvement CapEx. We do expect higher levels of capital improvement CapEx in fourth quarter due to the other spend this quarter. Consolidated AFFO per share growth in the quarter was almost 14%, resulting in year-to-date AFFO per share growth of over 12%. 
Moving on to Slide 9. We remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and our investment-grade credit rating. In late September, for example, we raised a total of $1 billion in unsecured senior notes with a weighted average maturity of over 7 years and historically low [indiscernible] rates for ADC. This transaction increased our average debt tenor to 5.3 years, increased our proportion of fixed-rate debt, which is now 76% overall, and even higher for U.S. funded debt at 80%. This transaction also allowed us to continue our long-held strategy of paying down our outstanding bank debt, which is primarily being used to support past acquisitions. This allows us to maximize our financial flexibility. 
In addition, as in the end of the third quarter, we achieved our goal of reducing our net debt to annualized adjusted EBITDA to 5x 3 months ahead of schedule. Longer term, our target leverage remains between 3 and 5x. In addition, we continue to be well protected from the impacts of potentially rising interest rates. In fact, the 25 basis point increase in LIBOR, [indiscernible] just to $9 million [ph] in impact to AFFO on an annualized basis. 
Turning to Slide 10. Given our solid year-to-date performance, continued improvements in foreign currency exchange rate forecast and Q4 growth expectations that are broadly consistent with our previous assumptions, we are raising our full year guidance. We are increasing the midpoint of our outlook for property revenue by $50 million or about 0.9%, resulting in projected full year growth of almost 22% or just over $1 billion. The increase is being driven by about a $25 million increase in past-due revenue and a $5 million increase in straight line revenue on an FX-neutral basis with remaining upside being driven by favorability from foreign exchange rate trends. Principally, that was generated in Q3. As in the past, our revised outlook does not contemplate impacts from pending transactions. 
Within our total revenue projections, we continue to expect U.S. organic tenant billings growth of about 5.8% for the year, which reflects a steady demand environment. Internationally, we expect organic tenant billings growth of over 13%, supported by strong trends in markets like Mexico and Ghana. We do expect slightly lower full year tenant billings growth in India, as compared to prior outlook, primarily due to carriers temporarily pausing some of their activities as they are waiting for the recent spectrum auctions to conclude. However, we anticipate that organic tenant billings growth in Asia would increase to the mid-teens level during Q4. 
At a consolidated level, organic tenant billings growth is expected to be nearly 8%. Day 1 revenue from sites added in the last year is expected to contribute to the balance of our anticipated tenant billings growth for the year just about 15%. The growth outlined above has resulted in a continued expansion of our base of noncancelable tenant lease revenue, which now stands at around $32.5 billion, with an average remaining lease term of 5.7 years on a consolidated basis and about 6.4 years for our big 4 wireless customers in the U.S. 
We're also raising the midpoint of our outlook for adjusted EBITDA by $25 million, resulting in expected full year growth of about 16% or roughly $500 million. The $25 million increase is being driven by a slight increase in net straight line, $15 million in and FX favorability and roughly $10 million in expense management outperformance relative to our previous expectations for the property segment. This is being partially offset by a slightly lower expected contribution from our services segment versus our prior outlook as a result of lower activity levels. 
Finally, we are raising our outlook for consolidated AFFO by $30 million or by over 1% at the midpoint, resulting in expected full year growth of about 15% or about $320 million. This $30 million increase is being driven primarily by about a $20 million increase in cash EBITDA and roughly $10 million in lower net interest expense. Assuming an average diluted share count of 429 million shares, this implies consolidated AFFO per share of $5.75 in the midpoint, reflecting a per share growth rate of over 13%. 
Before I move on, I'd also note that factoring in our October month to date actual FX rates and holding current spot rates constant for the rest of the year would result in additional upside of over $20 million for property revenue, $10 million for adjusted EBITDA and about $5 million of consolidate AFFO relative to the midpoints of our revised outlook. 
Turning to Slide 11. So far in 2016, we've demonstrated an ability to simultaneously deleverage the balance sheet, deploy meaningful capital to both our CapEx and acquisition programs and continue to fund a common stock dividend, which is expected to grow over 20% versus the prior year. Much of this is attributable to the significant internal cash flow generation capacity of our business, which is illustrated on this slide. As you can see, on a full year basis, our projected cash from operations of around $2.5 billion allows us to fully fund over $900 million in expected common stock dividends and more than $700 million in anticipated total capital expenditures, while at the same time leaving us around $1 billion of additional discretionary investment capacity. As a result, we've been able to close significant transactions like Viom as well as other smaller deals for a total of about $2.1 billion year-to-date and still reach our leverage target of 5x a full quarter earlier. This leaves us with around $300 million in incremental capacity for the fourth quarter. This estimate doesn't include any of the anticipated proceeds from our European JV transaction which we announced earlier today. Going forward, we would expect the internal cash flow generation capacity of our business to expand further as we continue to drive the high-margin conversion ratios on our organic revenue growth throughout our global footprint. 
In combination with being able to lever our incremental adjusted EBITDA growth, we would expect to have significant recurring investment capacity going forward. 
In addition, as we announced this morning, we've signed an agreement to form a strategic joint venture in Europe with PGGM. The formation of this joint venture, in addition to aligning us with a high-quality partner, will free up even more cash for us to deploy throughout our higher-growth markets. In addition, the JV has been established to explore and evaluate potentially invest in new market opportunities in Europe. By closing, we will contribute our [indiscernible] assets in ATC Europe and PGGM will acquire a 49% interest in this entity. American Tower will retain operational control and day-to-day oversight of the business. 
Turning to Slide 12. And in summary, we are well positioned for a strong finish to the year as our global business continues to generate solid growth across all of our key metrics. Our outlook now reflects consolidated AFFO per share growth of 13%, up from around 10% in our initial guidance provided in February. And we continue to expect dividend growth of over 20%. 
Looking forward, we believe we are poised to continue generating meaningful returns for investors for several key reasons: First, we are able to tap into the secular growth trends in mobile on a global scale, which we believe, when combined with our operational execution, will be the strong recurring growth across our existing asset base. Second, given our proven approach to capital allocation, a solid balance sheet with capital structure within our targeted range and healthy free cash flow generation, we will have significant capacity to either invest in our business or return directly back to stockholders. And lastly, we believe we will continue to be able to generate strong growth in our common stock dividend. Putting this all together, we believe that we have built a dynamic, sustainable long-term model for generating meaningful growth. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for some closing remarks before we take some Q&A. Jim?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. As is our tradition for third quarter calls, I'll focus today's remarks on wireless trends and technology. While the emphasis this morning is on the U.S., we expect similar trends to follow in our underserved markets. Mobile data usage cont
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. As is our tradition for third quarter calls, I'll focus today's remarks on wireless trends and technology. While the emphasis this morning is on the U.S., we expect similar trends to follow in our underserved markets. 
Mobile data usage continues to escalate rapidly. According to Cisco, the average U.S. smartphone now consumes more than 1.4 gigabits of data per month or a 1,700% increase from just 5 years ago. Video continues to power significant portion of that usage with advanced devices like the iPhone 7 and services to like YouTube and Netflix. Consequently, total mobile data usage in the U.S. is now at more than 500 terabytes per month. Despite this, 4G penetration is estimated at only 60% to 65% in the U.S. today, indicating that there is still significant growth to come simply from the device upgrade cycle as subscribers acquire more advanced handsets. 
So to keep pace with the strain these trends create on mobile network, the big 4 U.S. wireless carriers have consistently spent about $30 billion per year in CapEx since 2010, or roughly 15% of their total revenue in aggregate. And while the total spend has remained consistent, the per-gigabit cost for wireless carriers has dropped by more than 99% since 2005. This dramatic drop in expenses per gigabit has been supported through a combination of new spectrum, technology advancements and radio access network investments in these sites. We continue to believe that this level of capital intensity, which has been maintained over the last 10 years and has supported strong organic tenant billings growth for our business, is sustainable over the long term. 
In addition, over the past 5 years, the U.S. government has auctioned or otherwise made available close to 300 megahertz of new spectrum. We expect incremental spectrum assets, like AWS-3 and the WCS bands as well as the 700 megahertz spectrum that's been committed for the forthcoming public safety build-out, to be deployed over the next several years. 
As in the past, to fully capitalize on the availability of this spectrum, we anticipate that new antennas and radios will be placed on our towers, which should continue to help support healthy levels of growth for us in the U.S. 
We also expect the vast majority of these deployments in the near to medium term will take place on 4G macro tower networks, particularly given that the 5G standard isn't expected to be formalized until 2019. 
Meanwhile, technological advancements such as software-defined networks, self-optimizing networks and cloud REM, among others, continue to focus primarily on the mobile core network. These advancements have enabled mobile carriers to achieve significant savings on their core network operations, bringing up more resources for the radio access networks support. At the same time, macro towers remain the most cost- and technologically-efficient solution for radio signal propagation in the vast majority of areas across our country. 
Looking forward, we expect that improved devices, greater 4G penetration, more and better applications and consumers' behavior will continue to drive mobile data usage at a 30% to 40% annual growth rate. In addition, the expanding role of the Internet of things, or IOT, will add further demands on mobile networks. In the near to midterm, this network burn will be shouldered by 4G technology. We expect that any near-term 5G deployments will be extremely short-ranged, essentially used for fixed wireless solution. And furthermore, we expect that many early deployments of 5G will actually be indoors, where ATC is already a leading provider of indoor small cell networks today. Eventually, after the year 2020, we do think 5G technology will be widely applied for mobile applications, beginning first in dense urban areas, then spreading to suburban and rural areas predominately served by macro towers. This time line also coincides with the clearing process of the 600 megahertz spectrum that's currently being auctioned. To the extent that this spectrum is in fact used for a broad 5G coverage build-out, we believe it could be a significant benefit for our tower business, given the large size and substantial way the antennas required for optimal use of low band spectrum like 600 megahertz. To the extent you'd like some additional information on the evolution of 4G and the potential impacts of 5G on our business, I'd encourage all of you to reference the presentation we have posted on the company and industry resources section of the American Tower Investor Relations website. 
So to summarize, we believe that the U.S. is still probably in the fifth or sixth inning of 4G deployments and that further 4G equipment installations will still be largely on macro towers. In 5G, while initially a primarily fixed wireless broadband technology to compete with the likes of cable, is likely to eventually be deployed for mobile services across our macro tower infrastructure that mainly serves suburban and rural areas where most Americans live and commute. As a result, we expect to generate solid growth in the U.S. market for years to come. 
So with that, operator, please open the call up for questions.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Cusick.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Cusick.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about NBN Mexico. Looks like India was a big driver of strength this quarter, but you're guiding to a pause given the auction. Can you talk about what you're seeing lately and what you've seen from the Viom assets? And in Mexico, what does
componenttext: I wanted to ask about NBN Mexico. Looks like India was a big driver of strength this quarter, but you're guiding to a pause given the auction. Can you talk about what you're seeing lately and what you've seen from the Viom assets? And in Mexico, what does the runway look like there? It seems like 2 or 3 carriers are spending aggressively to deploy LTE. Is that still accelerating? And what do you see from the third carrier?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Phil. It's Jim. In India, there's now, that the actions are completed, and expectation on our part that we're going to see continued solid growth in our assets. And as far as performance between Viom and legacy ATC India, they're trending just about
componenttext: Sure, Phil. It's Jim. In India, there's now, that the actions are completed, and expectation on our part that we're going to see continued solid growth in our assets. And as far as performance between Viom and legacy ATC India, they're trending just about the same. So we've got solid growth on both sides of assets. And in India, there's going to be a significant 4G build-out led by our [indiscernible]  Reliance and we did recently signed a significant contract with one of the 4G players that's going to drive substantial new business for us starting in the fourth quarter and beyond. So we're really quite confident that India's going to meet our investment objectives.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the slowdown is sort of a quick planning slowdown, and you expect reacceleration early next year?
componenttext: So the slowdown is sort of a quick planning slowdown, and you expect reacceleration early next year?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think now that mobile operators understand the spectrum position and the resources, financial resources to achieve those. They're now going to be able to make solid plans for their next fiscal year, which for them starts -- or ends March for this y
componenttext: Yes. I think now that mobile operators understand the spectrum position and the resources, financial resources to achieve those. They're now going to be able to make solid plans for their next fiscal year, which for them starts -- or ends March for this year, begins in April for their next fiscal year. So it's just for a strong 2017 for us.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on Mexico?
componenttext: Okay. And on Mexico?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on Mexico, there is heightened competition. There is extensive deployment of 4G networks. Service pricing for subscribers has come down due to the competitive -- increasingly competitive wireless environment in the country. That's driving usage just a
componenttext: And on Mexico, there is heightened competition. There is extensive deployment of 4G networks. Service pricing for subscribers has come down due to the competitive -- increasingly competitive wireless environment in the country. That's driving usage just as it's done in the United States. And so we have really solid growth in Mexico. Our organic tenant billings growth there was more than 13% last quarter, and it will be at least 11%, maybe more, over the course of this full year. So Mexico is moving towards 4G. The obvious 3 major players there are AT&T, Telefónica and América Móvil. I think you have to refer to their own statements as to their exact schedules of deployment and casing. But in our business, we're seeing really solid growth from the whole industry.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Amir Rozwadowski.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Amir Rozwadowski.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you folks could talk about a bit more about the prospect for new spectrum deployment in the U.S. You did mention in your prepared remarks your expectations for new spectrum deployment such as AWS-3, WCS and FirstNet over the next few ye
componenttext: I was wondering if you folks could talk about a bit more about the prospect for new spectrum deployment in the U.S. You did mention in your prepared remarks your expectations for new spectrum deployment such as AWS-3, WCS and FirstNet over the next few years, but it does seem that we are close to the start date of the spectrum of -- deployment spectrum than we have been in the past. Any chance you can provide us with any additional insight here? And I've got a quick follow-up.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Amir. Again, it's Jim. On AWS-3, that -- those deployments are beginning. They're going to -- much more robust through 2017, again. And similarly, maybe a little bit beyond that for WCS. I'll pause on those 2 for a second because they're relatively
componenttext: Sure, Amir. Again, it's Jim. On AWS-3, that -- those deployments are beginning. They're going to -- much more robust through 2017, again. And similarly, maybe a little bit beyond that for WCS. I'll pause on those 2 for a second because they're relatively high-band spectrum to be augmenting what's out there today. Ultimately, that means that in addition to -- on many sites, not necessarily all sites, but many sites [indiscernible] amendments and also need to be eventually, a closer and more numerous array of transmission points to the get the same signal quality from higher-band spectrum such as this versus what's out there again deployed today in the 700, 800 band. So we expect amendments in mix of collocations going forward based on that new high-band spectrum being put into place. As the first [indiscernible] 700 megahertz spectrum, there's a scheduled to be a winner of the competition with the government selecting next month, in November. We are led to understand that based on the schedule that's out there today, that would infer probably mid-2017 and beyond deployment of actual equipment. And depending on the winner of the architecture and the rollout plan, we'd be able to comment further in the next few months on any impacts to our business, but we do expect them to be in a positive direction.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on your European JV. What has changed in terms of the market in terms of your interest in that market? I mean, clearly, you've had assets in the region for some time. We've seen some of the other companies there -- other some tower assets, the op
componenttext: And then on your European JV. What has changed in terms of the market in terms of your interest in that market? I mean, clearly, you've had assets in the region for some time. We've seen some of the other companies there -- other some tower assets, the operators some other tower assets. How are you thinking about that opportunity over the longer term?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're thinking about it today similarly as we have over the last 7 or 8 years, which is we're eager to get a strategic position of size in the European market, but we've only found one opportunity in Germany with KPN a few years ago where we can meet our
componenttext: We're thinking about it today similarly as we have over the last 7 or 8 years, which is we're eager to get a strategic position of size in the European market, but we've only found one opportunity in Germany with KPN a few years ago where we can meet our investment criteria as far as asset pricing and then the characteristics that we thought the business would evolve to over time, a relatively lower growth market. Our price points need to reflect that when we do asset purchases, and we'd like to and hope that there'll be more opportunities to achieve that over the next few years, Amir. What this joint ventures sets us up to do is should we -- and our partners at PGGM believe that we have a good opportunity, we'll be able to finance it much more efficiently. We could, in theory, do a large-scale move in Europe with our partner, with much less strain on our own balance sheet potentially. And PGGM is very attractive to us because not only have they been a long-term investor across many industries in Europe so we get the benefit of their insights on the region, they've also been very active in the tower space over the years. And we've dealt with them before. So we think we've got the best partner to ride along with us as we continue to evaluate and hope to find some European investments over the next few years and meet our investment criteria.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe -- I had a broad-level, Jim. We added a lot of LT coverage capacity a few years ago. Where are the carriers at a high level in terms of adding capacity? And do you think what's the breakdown look like in terms of amendments and maybe new cell sites?
componenttext: Maybe -- I had a broad-level, Jim. We added a lot of LT coverage capacity a few years ago. Where are the carriers at a high level in terms of adding capacity? And do you think what's the breakdown look like in terms of amendments and maybe new cell sites? And then just also clarification of India. I think you said next quarter, it's going to the mid-teens. From everything you know on India at this point, do you think this is kind of sustainable for a few years?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll start with the U.S. And I'll begin with coverage and capacity for LTE. Those are the country -- it's further public announcements that, reasonably solid coverage across all 4 of the major U.S. national carriers. And there's a lot of capacity wo
componenttext: Sure. I'll start with the U.S. And I'll begin with coverage and capacity for LTE. Those are the country -- it's further public announcements that, reasonably solid coverage across all 4 of the major U.S. national carriers. And there's a lot of capacity work that still needs to be done now. And the other piece of this, as I said, it's got higher-band spectrum and much more video content being run across the network, which indicates that you're going to have to have cell sites closer together. So the high-band spectrum because when you do carrier aggregation, you're also going to have to solve for the lowest common denominator spectrum, meaning the shortest transmission range. And as you get into 1.9, 2.1, 2.5 types of spectrum, you're going to have to have more numerous cell sites, frankly, over time. So that's still going to have to happen both for a capacity need, which is more [indiscernible] throughput as we talked about going to get that work and also the higher signal to call -- signal-to-noise call that you need to [indiscernible] travel as robustly. And secondly, we've got video, which requires much more powerful signal to be usable. So we still think there's, again, 3 or 4 good, solid innings, if not more, of 4G capacity and edge coverage deployment in front of us in the United States. The amendments in collocations, Tom, you can give the latest number on that.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the U.S., we've been roughly 70-30 amendment to colo. And interestingly enough, international it's been almost exactly the flip of it. It's been about 70% colo, 30% amendments. And I would expect that typical type of trend to occur over the next 6
componenttext: Yes. In the U.S., we've been roughly 70-30 amendment to colo. And interestingly enough, international it's been almost exactly the flip of it. It's been about 70% colo, 30% amendments. And I would expect that typical type of trend to occur over the next 6 to 12 months. We'll see what kind of impacts the -- some of the spectrum being deployed that Jim mentioned before. And with regards to India, we do expect a heightened activity in Q4. If you take a look at over the last 6 to 8 quarters in Asia, Tim, we've been in kind of that 10% to 13% kind of growth range on a organic kind of billings basis. And my sense is that's probably a fair range looking forward in that market. With the $10 billion that the carriers just spend on spectrum in the markets, we know that they're going to want to get that deployed. And so we see 4G activity going on in the market. So a lot of good things are happening in India, but I don't think the mid-teens type of the rate that we're going to see in Q4 is something that we'll see long term. I think it will revert back to some of the more traditional kind of 10% to 12% kind of growth rates.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, And I think to support those kind of 10% to 12% growth rates in a market like India, if you look at some of the real fundamentals there, first of all, the industry structure is rationalizing and becoming sustainable for long-term investment, right? S
componenttext: Yes, And I think to support those kind of 10% to 12% growth rates in a market like India, if you look at some of the real fundamentals there, first of all, the industry structure is rationalizing and becoming sustainable for long-term investment, right? So you're going to have probably half a dozen, at least, well-financed, scaled operators that can actually effectively and profitably deploy 4G across that vast country. So you got industry structure that's rationalizing. Secondly, spectrum and narrow bands and also very -- sort of fractionalized deployment of spectrum has been a limiting factor on mobile data deployment in India. That's been essentially cleaned up, if you will, or get rationalized with this latest auction and some of the smaller players either exiting, et cetera, giving those bigger players not only do have the financial capacity to do 4G, but now the spectrum position to do it effectively as well. So as a platform, you've got -- the industry, the spectrum in place to do it. And you've got a pattern of investments already by the carriers there that look a lot like those in the U.S. They're spending 15% to 20% of their revenue on capital expenditures similar to the U.S. did in its growth phase. There's $4.5 billion to $5 billion a year being spent in India by these carriers now. And they are -- they've got so much more to do because far below 25% of the subscribers have 3 or 4G. 75% to 85% of people in India are still literally on 2G, texting and talking on their phones. Incredible opportunity there. And then on top of everything else, you've got this catalyst of Reliance Jio out there sort of leading the market. So this low double-digit growth rate, as Tom suggested, we think can be sustained for quite sometime.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Barden.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Barden.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess first one would be, Tom, can you just put some numbers around this European JV? Specifically, how much money are you are getting? How did it value the portfolio? And kind of compare contrast the cost of funding that you think you can generate ther
componenttext: I guess first one would be, Tom, can you just put some numbers around this European JV? Specifically, how much money are you are getting? How did it value the portfolio? And kind of compare contrast the cost of funding that you think you can generate there versus in the U.S. And then second, just on the ForEx. Obviously, it's not a huge issue this quarter because it's working for us. But historically, you had approach to picking the guidance numbers for FX. I think it was the trailing 30 days or the consensus average forecast and given [indiscernible] how big the delta is between your guidance and the spot rate, I was wondering if you could kind of inform where that number comes from. And then lastly, just as a housekeeping item, I think you said something about maintenance CapEx being deferred in the quarter. I was wondering if you can cite that for us.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Dave. First of all, just on the European joint venture, we're looking to secure about $250 million -- or EUR 250 million on the transaction. So that gives you a sense of the kind of the sizing of it. And then as Jim and I both had mentioned, we
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Dave. First of all, just on the European joint venture, we're looking to secure about $250 million -- or EUR 250 million on the transaction. So that gives you a sense of the kind of the sizing of it. And then as Jim and I both had mentioned, we're using [indiscernible] our assets into a European JV we own and we operate it and control it, but we're really excited about having PGGM in the operation. And we'll look to bring that cash back and reinvest it, as we talked about it, in some other high-growth opportunities. We'll have additional capacity, as I also mentioned, because we would achieve our target leverage kind of 90 days before we [indiscernible] So that will leave us with roughly $300 million capacity, and then we'll have this additional EUR 250 million. So we feel good about how we're ending the year, where we are from the balance sheet perspective. On the FX side, you're right. As I've always kind of said, we know we're going to be wrong in terms of how we look at FX, but we are consistent. And so the forecast that we've used for the balance of the year is exactly as you laid out. It's more conservative of what's the year-end forecast would be that we find on, that we see the banks put out on Bloomberg over the last 90 days of an average spot rate. And so we've been very consistent with that. So the upside that we have included now in our outlook really includes the FX benefits that we generated versus our previous outlook in Q3. And so they're very little incremental Q4 FX upside, as you -- in our outlook. So [indiscernible] we just want to be a very consistent and very transparent in terms outlook at FX. It's well documented in our disclosures. And that's why then, even in the remarks I've made, we talked about some of the additional upside, Dave, that we might have relative to rates continuing as they are, spot rates for the balance of the year, and with that $20 million, I think, upside of revenue, which is principally coming from the real. It's -- you're right. The spot is significantly below where the forecasted range is. And it has been over the year, and that's provided us less headwinds, if you will, for the year and perhaps some upside for Q4. And then the -- you have some questions, Dave. What was the last one? Sorry.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was the maintenance CapEx referral I think you referred to in the script.
componenttext: It was the maintenance CapEx referral I think you referred to in the script.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the maintenance CapEx. It is seasonal. I mean, if go back and look at the trends for the last several years, we do generally have a pickup in the Q4. And that's usually -- that's largely being driven by some of the carriers themselves, but also just
componenttext: Yes, the maintenance CapEx. It is seasonal. I mean, if go back and look at the trends for the last several years, we do generally have a pickup in the Q4. And that's usually -- that's largely being driven by some of the carriers themselves, but also just our own ability to kind of close out the year. So we're probably looking at about a $10 million increment in Q4 versus Q3, at least that's what in the outlook.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Michael, it's Jim. Good morning. We're really going to stick to annual guidance that [indiscernible] comes from. We become such a diversified company know that we think we can have long-term double-digit AFFO per share growth using all of the mechanis
componenttext: And Michael, it's Jim. Good morning. We're really going to stick to annual guidance that [indiscernible] comes from. We become such a diversified company know that we think we can have long-term double-digit AFFO per share growth using all of the mechanisms and all of the markets that we have to work with going forward. And so therefore, yes, we're going to stick more to letting you know when we have timely information from the carriers and a pipeline with the annual growth rates look like in each market and sort of choose sort of aspirational objectives, given we're going to be transitioning from 4 to 5G and operating now on 13 markets. So we'll do that on an annual basis going forward.

componenttext: And if I can just follow up, given some of the comments that you've made on timing for spectrum deployments and some of the higher-level schemes that you see impacting site leasing revenues over the next few years, what should investors' expectations be around the timing of new MLA opportunities with some of your large customers?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, yes, it's Jim. Those are really specific to the situation with the carrier. What's the existing agreement? How long does it last? Do they have a new build plan coming upon them that they want to talk about a longer-term rearrangement of it -- of
componenttext: Michael, yes, it's Jim. Those are really specific to the situation with the carrier. What's the existing agreement? How long does it last? Do they have a new build plan coming upon them that they want to talk about a longer-term rearrangement of it -- of the contracts? So there's really no way to predict when a mobile operator is going to want to renegotiate an MLA. And what I think what you can expect from us is consistent communication with the mobile operators. Our goal, as I've said, is to achieve the most value for our assets and for our investors while also providing a path to the mobile operator for the most efficient lifecycle cost for the deployment of the infrastructure that they expect they're going to need and try to find that common ground. And so that's what we will always continue to do it. And it will take different forms of agreement and then it will take different timing of agreement based on the specific carrier's interests and needs.

componenttext: Two questions, if I may. First, on U.S. churn, if I look at 2016 year-to-date versus 2015, we've seen that moderate. And I'm just curious if your expectation will be that should continue? I guess, more specifically, if there's any other consolidation or items we should still be thinking about. Just a reminder on that if we're getting back to normal levels. And then you've touched on a little bit already in the call, but around amendments versus new colo opportunity. And appreciate that it's been largely amendments last year, it's been largely amendments this year. expected large amendments next year. But as I'm sure you can appreciate, investors are debating if that's a structural change on that something that simply timing and part of that is around small cell. And while appreciate the small cells are more expensive to build and is more efficient to deploy a macro, the [indiscernible] to some degree our capital-constrained as they do need to be building out small cells, and something assessed of items over the making the investment, one could argue that it seems to be self-splitting. And I'm jus curious, where the confidence comes from that do think at some point we will see the cell splitting aspect kind of come back into vogue?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: First of all, on the churn side, the 2015, as I recall, we had some smaller customers churn off. And so our churn rates in that 1.5%, 1.8%, 2% kind of range. So I would expect that kind of churn rate to continue.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the whole equation, if you will, of amendments, collocation, small cells, the amendment collocation percentage has drifted and varied over time, depending again with the carriers are doing with their networks. And the reality of how regional real es
componenttext: So on the whole equation, if you will, of amendments, collocation, small cells, the amendment collocation percentage has drifted and varied over time, depending again with the carriers are doing with their networks. And the reality of how regional real estate managers and the mobile operators or regional network managers operate is that they get a budget every year. And they're going to use that budget, whether it's $5 million or $10 million or $50 million for their region for that period, they're going to use that budget on the most efficient way they can determine to solve the network issues that they have in front of them. And we've got pretty close experience with a lot of these folks. And their list of things to do seems to always exceed the budget they have awarded to them for that year. So there's always network needs to either increase capacity, improve coverage, and limit their own churn off, to meet growing demand, et cetera. And the list exceeds the budget. So the shakeout of amendments versus colos it's really what solves the most problems in that given year. And there's always more amendments and more colos than they can actually do. When it comes to small cells, as you just indicated, that's probably the least efficient, especially outdoor small cells, the least efficient option of these individuals to spend their budget. And so they spend that budget in the places only the times, only a small cells as a [indiscernible] when they have to do so. And so our experience on the total spend going to a macro site-type deployments versus small cell-type deployments, we've said in the past is around 5% of what we can see right now going to small cells and perhaps, over the next 5 years, that can go as high as 10% of the total with a total itself growing because of the percentage of revenue and revenue growing. So we really don't see wholesale shifts in the spending pattern or the habits of the people that we deal with in the field on the front line of the mobile operators. And hopefully, that addresses a question.

But you actually lowered your outlook for organic billings growth in the international segment. So I was hoping you could just kind of close that gap for us.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I just wanted to go back to the JV really quickly to understand what you're doing. Are you effectively selling 49% of the business you have right now in Europe, meaning all the cash will be coming back to you? Or you're actually planning o
componenttext: Great. And then I just wanted to go back to the JV really quickly to understand what you're doing. Are you effectively selling 49% of the business you have right now in Europe, meaning all the cash will be coming back to you? Or you're actually planning on leaving some of that to fund the JV? And then regardless, if the JV finds investment opportunities going forward, is that going to be funded, kind of on an as-needed basis, meaning they'll be calling on capital and strive to maintain at least a 51% ownership as you do more deals?

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would -- it's not a sale, Brett. I mean, we're contributing the assets, and PGGM is going to be our investing partner in that new joint venture. And yes, the cash that we are going to be receiving for that 49% is going to be reinvested in other par
componenttext: Yes, I would -- it's not a sale, Brett. I mean, we're contributing the assets, and PGGM is going to be our investing partner in that new joint venture. And yes, the cash that we are going to be receiving for that 49% is going to be reinvested in other parts of the business, coming back to the U.S. We'll determine where we're going to put it. But yes, that is leaving the JV.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brett, just to give a little bit of [indiscernible] as to why we're going forward with this. First of all, it really is an initiative that achieves objectives in all 3 of our sort of strategic pillars that we have in place for the last 15 years since I've
componenttext: Brett, just to give a little bit of [indiscernible] as to why we're going forward with this. First of all, it really is an initiative that achieves objectives in all 3 of our sort of strategic pillars that we have in place for the last 15 years since I've been CEO here. The first of those pillars, it's to put ourselves in a situation where we can achieve strategic positioning in a leadership rank of independent tower companies or mobile infrastructure companies in all the most populous regions of the world, all right? And we have that in the U.S. We have that in Latin America. We have that in India. We have that in Africa. And in Europe, we'd like to pursue other avenues to achieve that as long as they meet our investment criteria. So for strategic positioning, PGGM is an excellent partner for us in the region to give us a wider window for potential expansion into the market -- again, if and only if we can meet our ATC investment criteria, which, as you know, is pretty strict. The second of our strategic pillars is to be -- in our aspiration, the top execution, experience and operator in this space in the world, right? I think PGGM has stepped up and validated with us that we are the partner of choice and that we can then team up with others with regional experience or regional positioning to try to achieve that growth aspiration. And thirdly, it's therapeutic to our balance sheet. We've always wanted a strong balance sheet along the way over the last 15 years. We've maintained investment-grade for many, many years, in spite of a growing the business very dramatically, as you've seen us do. And we are going to get proceeds from this that will both help our leverage position in the short term and allow us to redeploy it into newer growth opportunities in the mid to long term. So I think that, really, this arrangement hits all 3 of our strategic pillars: strategic positioning, validates our operational expertise and is conductive to our balance sheet strategy.

componenttextpreview: Wondered if you can talk a little bit about your broadcast business in North America and any change that you may be foresee given the broadcast auctions and maybe the change and the configurations on your broadcast towers. And then on Africa, if you could
componenttext: Wondered if you can talk a little bit about your broadcast business in North America and any change that you may be foresee given the broadcast auctions and maybe the change and the configurations on your broadcast towers. And then on Africa, if you could maybe just give us an update. I think there's been some tuck-in acquisitions in some of those smaller markets with Nigeria and maybe some of your -- the trends that you're seeing with respect to MTN and Vodafone and CapEx trends in that market and across the continent.

headline: American Tower Corporation (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jonathan. It's Jim. As far as our broadcast business, it's mid-single-digit percent of our revenue, a really solid piece of our business, which has very long-term contracts, as you know, in the TV and radio space. And with the incentive auctions goi
componenttext: Sure, Jonathan. It's Jim. As far as our broadcast business, it's mid-single-digit percent of our revenue, a really solid piece of our business, which has very long-term contracts, as you know, in the TV and radio space. And with the incentive auctions going on now, they're going to be a few moving parts that we think we're really in an excellent position to sort of address and take advantage of. You may recall, 3 or 4 years ago, we acquired Richland Towers, which was, I guess, the second-largest independent in the space. And so we have a really solid position to help the broadcasters that either retain or divest some of the spectrum to stay on air, right? So they're going to have to have sites that are both simultaneously transmitting in the market while equipment is being taken down or put up. So we will have plenty of sites for them to move to in the process. And we'll be able to be, we think, the real estate provider of choice as this TV station shuffle of spectrum and channels goes through. So we think it's going to be a nice solid growth business, It's going to contribute to our U.S. operations for many years here. As far as the small deals that we're doing, it's the same disciplined investment process that we've had in place for years and years. We've got these very highly qualified teams, I would describe them as, across all the continents globally, that are continuing to always look for opportunities for us to invest and meet our criteria of those investments and get AFFO-accretive deals for us. And sometimes, those are big, like in Viom or Verizon or and sometimes those are modest size, like in South Africa. We are acquiring Eton Towers, adding about 300 sites to our portfolio. It makes a ton of sense for us tactically and strategically, and we'll go ahead and do those smaller deals. Now in Africa, as you saw from Tom's presentation, is one of our fastest-growing regions. Much like India, there's incredible need and demand, not only currently, but far into the future, for mobile service there. There are very low-cost handsets that are going to accelerate the adoption of 3 and 4G in people in those countries that really, really need it. And we've got kind of a pole position there. Certainly, in South Africa, we are the independent leader. In Nigeria, we're one of the top 2. In Ghana and Uganda, we are also the clear leader as independents, we feel. So we've got a really good strategic position in the country that we need to be in there, and the trends are going to be very similar for the mid to long term in Africa, as they will be in India, where we think we can sustain double-digit growth rates. And I also just want to further clarify, provide some color on Brett's question on the JV. I mean, we expect this JV to be platform for us to be able to expand in the region. And I'm not going to get into any the details relative to the JV agreement, but there's always a process within the agreement to the extent that the carriers aren't able to or don't desire to for one to be able to expand in the market without the other. So just wanted to make sure that, Brett, I gave that additional color to you.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, Ric, the answer is yes. I mean, to the extent, more euro is being generated in the market, there's I think going to be more opportunities to be able to raise capital on that in the market. So the business itself, in Germany, as you know, is not a significant business for us overall from a consolidated perspective. So we don't have significant amounts of euros being generated. We have been able to candidly pull out a fair amount of cash from the business over the last 3 or 4 years since we bought it. But we're hopeful to the extent, that if this platform proves successful, and as Jim said, we have deals over there that make sense for us that we would be able to increase our exposure into the marketplace. And relative to multiples and things like that, we're really going to not be able to do it be able to discuss any of those. I think we feel really good about the values that have been ascribed to this business. And I think we [indiscernible] as Jim said, have a really solid platform to be able to look at other opportunities therapeutic to the balance -- all of the things that you mentioned in terms of supporting our strategic goals in the business really excited about this opportunity.

We expect to be at that 5x or below. Clearly, with this kind of cash that we're going to be getting from the JV and the additional capacity that we have. So we feel really good in terms of the ability to hit our targets that we laid out in the beginning of the year. It positions us well for next year.
